page.topic: Getting Started With Alpha Anywhere - Build Your First Mobile App
page.description: Follow this step-by-step guide to your first Alpha Anywhere application to run in a mobile web environment.

section.description: The mobile application you will be creating will interct with the Northwind Access database which ships with Alpha Anywhere. In order to access the data in the Northwind database, you must first create a connection string to communicate with the database.

step.description: First, copy the Northwind Access database to a folder in your "Documents" directory. In order to perform CRUD actions against the Northwind database, it must reside inside a folder you have read/write permissions. Typicially, this would be a directory inside the C:\Users folder on Windows.

Next, create a connection string to the Northwind database by creating a new AlphaDAO Connection. From the Web Projects Control Panel, select *[ui:[ManageConnStr] Manage Connection Strings]* > *[ui:Alpha DAO Connection strings]* from the *[ui:Edit]* menu to create a new connecton string.

figure.title: Open the AlphaDAO Connections dialog.
The AlphaDAO Connections Dialog.

step.description: Create a new connection string, named "Northwind", to connect with the Northwind Access database that you copied to a folder in your Users directory.

figure.title: Creating a new connection to the Northwind Access database.

description.p: The Connection Type for your new connection string is "Access" and should be selected by default for new connection strings when the Create SQL Connection String dialog is opened.
For the *[ui:File Name]* option in the Create SQL Connection String dialog, select the Northwind Access database.

figure.title: The Create SQL Connection String dialog.
Select the Northwind database you copied to the Users directory.

step.description: Verify the connection to the Northwind Access database is correct by clicking the "Test Connection" button. If everything is configured properly, it will display the "Success!" message. Save the connection string and return to the Web Projects Control Panel.

figure.title: Success! The connection string works.
The connection string dialog listing the Northwind connection

section.description: Your connection string to the Northwind Access database is configured and ready to go! Let's start building our mobile app.
Components are the basic building blocks of any Alpha Anywhere application. You will be creating a UX Component that will contain the entire mobile application. Let's get started.

section.title: Adding a New Component to the Web Project

step.description: Add a new UX Component to your project by clicking the *[ui:[FileNew]New]* button in the Web Projects Control Panel toolbar.

figure.title: The Web Projects Control Panel toolbar.

step.description: In the New File dialog, select *[ui:Web Component]* and click the *[ui:Next >]* button.

figure.title: The New File dialog.

step.description: Select *[ui:UX]* from the components listed and click *[ui:Next >]*. This will create a new UX Component.

figure.title: Selecting the type of component to create.

step.description: A number of templates for the UX Component are available. These templates make building some types of applications faster. You will be creating a blank UX Component to start. Select *[ui:Start with a blank UX Component]* option and click *[ui:OK]*. This creates a new, blank UX Component.

figure.title: Select UX Component Template
The UX Builder

step.description: Finally, save your new component by clicking the *[ui:[FileSave]Save]* button on the toolbar at the top of the screen.

figure.title: Save Your UX Component

section.description: Next, you will start adding controls to the UX Component, creating the core controls needed to view, add, and modify data in the the Northwind database.

section.title: Adding a New List Control
section.description: The List Control is one of the core building blocks in most mobile applications. Using the *[ui:[ListGenie]List Control - Quick Setup Genie]*, you will create a List with a Detail View and Search part for interacting with the Customers table in the Northwind database.

step.description: The interface for the UX Component is designed on the *[ui:[UXControls] Controls]* pane. Insert a new List control into the UX Component by clicking *[ui:[ListCtrl] [List]]*

figure.title: Insert a new List Control

step.description: When a control is inserted into the component, Alpha Anywhere presents you with the option to insert multiple controls at once. The application you are building only needs one List control. If it is not selected, choose *[ui:Create a new Single Control]* and enter a *[ui:Name]* for your List. Once you have given the List a name, click the *[ui:[ListGenie]List Control - Quick Setup Genie]* button at the bottom of the *[ui:New Control]* dialog.

figure.title: Create a new List Control

section.title: Connecting the List to a Database

step.description: Next, you will configure your List control to connect to the Northwind database using the connection string created earlier (See [Build a Database Connection String].) Select the *[...]* button for *[ui:Connection string]* to open the *[ui:Connection String]* dialog.

figure.title: The List Control - Quick Setup Genie.

step.description: In the *[ui:Connection String]* dialog, select *[ui:Use a named connection string]*. Open the list of named connection strings by clicking the *[ui:Select...]* button.

figure.title: Selecting a named connection in the Connection Strng dialog.

step.description: Select the *[[db]Northwind]* connection string from the list and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Selecting Northwind from the AlphaDAO Connection Strings dialog.

step.description: Now that the *[ui:Connection string]* is configured, you can setup the *[ui:Table name]* and *[ui:Fields list]* for the List control.

figure.title: Connection string is now configured in the List Control - Quick Setup Genie.

step.description: Click the *[ui:...]* button for the *[ui:Table name]* property to choose the table that will be used to populate the data in the List control. Choose the *[[tbl]Customers]* table from the Northwind database.

figure.title: Select the Customers table.

description.p: Next, configure the *[ui:Field list]* property. The *[ui:Field list]* property determines what fields will be available for displaying, searching, and editing in the List. If you plan on editing table data, you must select the table's ID field must be included in the *[ui:Selected Fields]*. The ID field for the Customers table is *[CustomerID]*.
Select the *[CustomerID]*, *[CompanyName]*, *[Address]*, *[City]*, and *[Country]* fields from the Customers table and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Selecting the Fields that will be available in the List control to view and modify.
The *[ui:List Data Source Definition]* completely configured to work with the Customers table in the Northwind database.

section.title: Setting Up the Detail View
section.description: Next, you will configure the List control's Detail View. The Detail View is used for editing or adding data to the Customers table in the Northwind database.

step.description: Check the *[ui:Has Detail View]* box to add a Detail View to the List control.

figure.title: Add a Detail View to the List control.

section.description: That's it! Now we'll add a Search part to the List Control so you can search the Customers table for specific records.

section.title: Adding a *[ui:Search Part]*
section.description: Now, you will add a *[ui:Search Part]* to your List control.

step.description: In the *[ui:Search Part]* Properties section, click the checkbox for *[ui:Has Search Part]*.

figure.title: Adding a *[ui:Search Part]* to the List control.

step.description: You will be creating a Keyword search part. For the *[ui:Search Part type]* property, click the *[ui:...]* button and select "*[ui:SingleKeywordControl]*" in the [*ui:Select Search Style]* dialog and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: The *[ui:Select Search Style]* dialog.

step.description: Next, select the fields to search in the List control when a seach is executed. Click the *[ui:...]* button for the *[ui:Search Part fields]* property and select all of the fields and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Select all of the fields in the List control to search.

step.description: Finally, check the box for *[ui:Delay populate List till active search]*. This option indicates that the List control should not be populated with any data from the Customers table until a search is performed.

figure.title: The *[ui:Search Part]* configured to add seach capabilities for the List control.

section.title: Adding Disconnected Support
section.description: The final step in setting up our List control with Detail View and Search Part is to add Disconnected support. This allows your mobile app to continue to work when a connection to the internet or netework where a database may be stored is lost.

step.description: In the *[ui:Disconnected Operation]* properties, check the box for *[ui:Persist List data to Local Storage]*.

figure.title: Enabiling offline capabilities for your mobile application.

section.title: Generate and Preview the List, Detail View, and Search Part
section.description: The List Control - Quick Setup Genie confguration is now complete. Next, you will generate the controls and preview the UX Component to see what you created.

step.description: Click the *[ui:OK]* button in the *[ui:List Control - Quick Setup Genie]*. This will generate all of the controls necessary for the List, Detail View, and Search Part. Your UX Component should have a list of controls similar to the ones shown in the image below:

figure.title: The controls created by the *[ui:List Control - Quick Setup Genie]*

step.description: Click the *[ui:[FileSave] Save]* button to save your UX Component.

description.p: Congratulations! You have a working application!

To preview what your application looks like, click on the *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]* tab located next to the *[ui:[Design] Design]* and *[ui:[LPreview] Live Preview]* tabs at the top of the *[ui:UX Builder]*.

figure.title: The Working Preview Window.

description.p: Try it out! Type "Spain" into the Search box and click the *[ui:Search]* button to populate the list. Now you can click on records and edit them in the Detail View, located to the right of the List control. Click the *[ui:[FileSave] Save]* button to save your changes. A little yellow icon will appear next to the record in the List control indicating that it has been modified. To save the change to the database, click *[ui:[FileSave] Synchronize]*.

Because disconnected application features are enabled, the List control will remember the records shown when you exit *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]*. Click on the *[ui:[Design] Design]* tab and then back on the *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]* tab. The List control will remain populated with the data that was in it when you navigated away from *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]*.

figure.title: Searching for "Spain" yeilds several records in the List control.
The List control remembers not only what records were displayed but keeps track of changes to records that haven't been saved back to the Northwind database.

section.description: Now that you have the functional components of the mobile application working, let's configure the UX Component to look and feel like a mobile application.

group.title: Building a Mobile App: Adding Panels

description.p: All mobile applications built in Alpha Anywhere use Panels. Panels group controls into "screens" and provide the navigation between "screens" of your application. You will be adding 3 Panels and a Panel Navigator to your UX Component.
When you are finished, the UX Component controls will look similar to the controls shown in the image below.

figure.title: The List, Search, and Detail View in a Panel Layout.

step.description: Select all of the Search Part controls in the UX Component. Click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]* listed in the *[ui:Panels]* section. Click *[ui:OK]* to insert the Panel Card around the selected controls.

figure.title: Place the Search Part in a Panel Card.

step.description: Next, wrap the List control in a Panel Card. Selec the list control in the Tree View and click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]*. When prompted, click the *[ui:Insert Around]* button to place the List inside the Panel Card.

figure.title: Wrapping the List control in a Panel Card.

step.description: Add a Panel Card around the Detail View the same way as you did for the Search Part. Select all the Detail View controls and click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]*. Click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Adding a Panel Card around the Detail View.

step.description: Now you must remove the Container controls from the UX. Select the the *[ui:[Container:CONTAINER_1]]* and *[ui:[Container End:CONTAINER_1]]* controls and delete them by clicking the [DelObj] button.

figure.title: Removing CONTAINER_1.

step.description: Select the the *[ui:[Container:CONTAINER_1_2]]* and *[ui:[Container End:CONTAINER_1_2]]* controls and delete them as well by clicking the [DelObj] button.

figure.title: Removing CONTAINER_1_2.

step.description: Next, add a Panel Navigator to the UX Component. Select all of the controls in the UX Component and clic *[ui:[PNav][Panel Navigator]]* in the *[ui:Panels]* section.

figure.title: Add a Panel Navigator

video.name: Swiping between Panels Using the Mouse.

section.description: Now that you have the bare bones of the application working, you will now add the layout and styling necessary to make it usealbe on a mobile device. This starts with converting the List's layout from a Column Layout to a Freeform layout, allowing you to take advantange of client-side templates to render the data in a more mobile-friendly fashion.

step.description: Open the List Builder for the List control. On the *[ui:List Properties]* tab, change the Layout from *[ui:Column]* to *[ui:Freeform]*

figure.title: Changing the layout type for a List control.

step.description: On the List Layout tab, click the *[ui:Pre-defined Templates]* link located along the bottom of the Template editor. This will open the List Template Picker. Select the template with Level1, Level2, and Detail on the Left with Context on the right.

figure.title: One of the pre-defined templates availalbe in the List Template Picker

step.description: Assign the fields from the List control to the placeholders in the pre-defined template. You can select the fields from the dropdown controls or type them in manually. You can assign multiple fields to the same placeholder by typing them in.

figure.title: Assigning fields to template placeholders

step.description: The placeholders in the list template will be replaced with the fields you picked. This will produce a template that will look similar to the following:
step.example:
{CustomerID}
{CompanyName}
{Address}
{City} {Country}

section.description: When we view the UX component in Working Preview, the data in the List control wiil be rendered using the Freeform template you created.

figure.title: The List rendered using the freeform template.
